newsitem.title: FRANCE: French union head does not expect big strikes.
newsitem.headline: French union head does not expect big strikes.

text.p: The head of France's largest labour union, the CFDT, said on Tuesday she did not expect the government's tough budget austerity plans to spark a rerun of last year's strikes which paralysed the country.
"I really don't see it happening," Nicole Notat, the union's secretary general, told the France Inter radio.
She was asked if unhappiness over the government's plans for 1997 could trigger the same kind of public sector protests seen in November and December last year.
She said, however, that she believed that the autumn would be marked by sporadic labour unrest.
French unions had been predicting a tough ride for the government over its belt-tightening programme, but of late their warnings have sounded more muted.
So far, only unions in the education sector have clearly talked of a strike to protest against job cuts expected under the 1997 budget.
Statements by the Communist-led CGT and the Force Ouvriere, which spearheaded last year's strikes, did not herald massive upheaval, Notat said.
The CGT, Notat said, was sounding "very low-key".
Marc Blondel, head of Force Ouvriere "is having a family gathering in Paris," she said, referring to the union's plans for a big protest march on September 21.

"All of this does not seem to indicate a very, very big enthusiasm...Perhaps simply because we know today that it's not enough to press on a button. The will of union leaders alone is not sufficiient for people to spring into action," she said.
Conservative Prime Minister Alain Juppe has said that the 1997 budget will freeze spending at 1996 levels, implying a spending cut of about 60 billion francs.
The move is a key step to reducing France's core deficit to three percent of gross domestic product as part of a drive to qualify for joining a single European currency.
